title: Thursday, 19th July, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:06 am
BE11:07am

Hello!

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Soundbuy Oi!
FT_reader morning! anything on Smiths Group?
BE11:07am

Welcome to Markets Live, a daily markets ramble thing in this quiet corner of the most buttoned-up newspaper in Britain and quite possibly the world.

Alchemy30 morning
BE11:08am

( https://www.thegua...-for-the-1-percent )

Call me Papi And the Fat Controller at SPD

BE11:09am

BornCynic Morning
VV75 morning

Pharma How to Spend It should only be read as satire.
BornCynic After looking at the pictures of the female models and shouting "eat food" at them..........
sprout If the Guardian's numbers are right it's quite nice that Russian oligarchs and Chinese billionaires are subsidising quality journalism for the rest of us.
Deep Breath everyone... MUNTERS! - the company please, not you guys
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Anyway ............................

undefined
BE11:13am

Where to begin?

Blank canvas Babcock getting battered?
11:13 am
Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 718.00, down 85 (-10.59%), High: 751.60, Low: 709.60, Volume: 2.71m
Ethelred Any views on Babcock? 10% down on slightly meh trading statement
BE11:14am

.... seems as good a place as any.

BE11:14am

Rather complicated statement from Babcock, which on the face of it stuck with earnings guidance.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Revenue, though, is worse.

BE11:15am

"low-single-digit" organic growth for FY19 now.

Ethelred revenue may well be worse but £400m in market cap worse?
BE11:15am

It had previously been low mid-single digit

i Oversold?
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Land and marine are the issues, all possibly one-off .... but when you're a government outsourcer you don't get much in the way of forgiveness for surprises.

BE11:17am

Jefferies:

BE11:17am

The c.£60-110m shortfall is attributed to three factors: 1) a temporary £60-70m slowdown relating to infrastructure spend, submarine disposal and the Dreadnought project as the newly-launched Submarine Delivery Agency reviews the timing of its expenditure programme; 2) restructuring of the Defence Equipment & Support organisation is contributing to slightly slower-than-expected activity levels in the Land division (£30m); 3) recent management changes at Eskom have resulted in power station outage delays in H1 (small).

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Against that you have margins better, slightly.

Ethelred Exepct afternoon rebound as shorters (6%) take advantage
BE11:17am

The FY19E EBITA margin is now expected to be slightly ahead of the “broadly stable” guidance provided at the May prelims due to non-core asset disposals (a 10bp tailwind to the pro-forma EBITA margin) and a c8% margin in Land (versus previous guidance of a stable 7.6% margin) as momentum in low-margin procurement expenditure remains slow.

Tsetse Did the GBP just slip under 1.30?
BE11:18am

So ..... Higher bid pipeline, stable order book, leverage targets maintained .....

alewis2005 morning all
11:18 am
BE11:19am

.... but all that's overshadowed by organic growth in the range of 2% to 3.5% for the year, when the consensus was a percentage point or so above that.

BE11:19am

Here's Goldman.

BE11:19am

Overall we view the trading update as mixed and see the reduced organic growth expectations for FY19 raising uncertainty in the market, especially on UK defence environment and spending. However, we note the increase in bid pipeline and expect that to be supportive of organic growth going into FY20.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

And RBC.

BE11:20am

We would have preferred a more benign update from the group, given the need for consistency around the messaging in order to drive a re-rating from current levels. Whilst there have been a number of good wins since the start of the year and importantly a good blend between the UK and International, the slowdown in Marine and Land (albeit looks like timing given the pickup in the Marine bid pipeline) is likely to get attention today. However, we continue to believe the market is overplaying concerns around margins and cash flow generation and as these subside, the current CY19E PE of 9x, FCF Yield of 9% and 4% DY could look very generous. With material corporate activity unlikely, leverage on a trajectory towards 1x will provide additional return potential and this underpins our positive stance.

Manxish Morning each
BE11:22am

So you can see 10% off Babcock as an overreaction. Or you can see that, in a sector that gave us Capita and Carillion among many others, folk can be a bit nervous around unexpected events.

11:22 am
undefined
i I personally think it is an overreaction is an nervous environment
BE11:23am

Munters?!?

BE11:24am

I'm not sure we've ever mentioned Munters here.

Ethelred Argaubly not in the same sector as Carillion and Capita.... high value ad engineering aint watering potplants and guys on front desk security
Pseudonym Any chance the EU countries might start trying to hit NATO spending targets?
11:24 am
BE11:24am

(@Ethelred: are you long by any chance?)

Ethelred Not as exposed as I used to be (fortunately)
BE11:25am

But, sure, okay I guess. Here we go with some Swedish dehumidifier chat.

L'Hermitte Any comments on the spectacular own GOAL? Down 1/3 at one stage.
Alchemy30 Was there anymore to the Aggreko comment yesterday, not particularly strong today
BE11:25am

Q1 misses. Datacentres are the problem.

i Positive is diversified internationally and stronger margins update.
11:26 am
BE11:26am

2Q group organic order intake down 20%

BE11:27am

Here comes Kepler.

nichoman am nibbling some pounds at 1.30. for all the hysteria it seems to me like recent shenanigans make it more likely we get may's plan, Norway or jersey type deal or No Brexit.
i disposing the non-performing projects and refocusing on higher margin stuff is in the longer-term more beneficial
BE11:27am

The absence of large data-centre orders was well known. Weaker orders were mainly explained by the largest business area, Air Treatment, which had a 10% organic decline – bearing in mind that the comparison is tough. Still, as expected, earnings improved by more than 20%. A somewhat softer growth outlook means we trim our forecast by around 10%. Nevertheless, Munters’s energyefficient offering is still backed up by exposure to fast-growing segments, such as lithium batteries and data centres. The report triggered a negative share price reaction, and we find the share attractively priced at an EV/EBITDA of 9-11x. We keep our Buy rating. Our TP is revised downwards to SEK50 (SEK56), mainly based on a peer valuation.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

And Goldman.

BE11:28am

Results aside, during the conference call, the outlook for medium-term growth and margins came into question. Munters’ share price closed down 12% yesterday, prompted (in our view) by ongoing disappointment in Data Centers and commentary regarding alternative technologies, pricing pressure and an increasing numbers of competitors. We believe investors should view, until stronger numbers are printed, Munters’ equity story excluding Data Centers. And, with limited reason to get excited about Munters’ other divisions, we believe Munters should trade at a discount to European Capital Goods (vs. a valuation previously in line)

BornCynic Good article BE - thank you - a more catchy article title might have been "the Devil wears Prada at the FT"?
BE11:28am

They note net debt to EBITDA ratio of 2.9x, though covenant's at 5x.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Shares down 2.8% live.

undefined
Soundbuy Swedish dehumidifies - with all those saunas?? Hmmm...............
BE11:29am

On Aggreko ............ nope! No idea.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

They did well yesterday afternoon but we couldn't find a rumour to attach to the strength worth reporting.

BE11:31am

Ashtead or United Rentals mentioned elsewhere, though. Not by us.

BE11:31am

Liberum doesn't think a lot of those names.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

We would be surprised to see such a deal transpire given the stated strategy of both companies. Although we acknowledge that as part of URI ‘s recent acquisition of BakerCorp that it stated it would consider future growth in Europe, we would note that such a move is like to take a year or two before it occurs. As for Ashtead it has typically focused on smaller bolt-on acquisitions and like URI has invested a significant amount in recent years in building its own generator and temperature control business. We also question whether either company would be that interested in Aggreko’s developing market exposure given the risk profile that this would add to both businesses. On a fundamental basis we continue to remain cautious on Aggreko given the competition it is facing in developed markets as well as the level of recovery on its long-term receivables.

Aggreko PLC (AGK:LSE): Last: 693.80, down 3.8 (-0.54%), High: 703.40, Low: 684.40, Volume: 1.21m
Alchemy30 Thanks
BE11:32am

It's not implausible, I guess, that Aggreko became a PE target.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Net debt's sub 1x, I think, and you can make an argument for valuation being compressed by short-termism.

MonkeyTrader Any word on IWG.....the put-up-or-shut-up deadline is coming up. A few of the big holders seem to be getting nervous. Maybe the lack of news is un-nerving!
BE11:33am

Note also, though, that Aggreko has results due at the start of August and the outlook statement is going to be very hard to predict.

undefined

On IWG, I can only reiterate that if there was anything to say with regards the lineup of bidders etc they would've had to have told us.

We have some incoming from investors following yesterday’s FT article
reporting speculation that Allianz could consider Prudential a potential
takeover target. However, we don’t believe such a deal will happen

BE11:39am

Prudential was squeezed amid a revival of speculation among traders that the insurer might be a takeover target ahead of a planned demerger of its UK and European division. Chinese insurers were linked to the theory along with Allianz, even though the German group last month played down the likelihood of major acquisitions.

11:39 am

.... which agrees exactly with what you write.

BE11:40am

In our view, Allianz is mainly keen in buying non-life rather than life
business and Prudential is predominantly a life insurer.

There's another six or so pars explaining why Allianz probably won't buy Pru. US business "would be of very limited interest" and so forth.

None of which we'd contest, because we nodded to it in the original story. The bit that seems to have been overlooked, you could argue, is the Chinese link.

It overtakes my recent favourite, which was this one from Sports Direct: https://investegat...1806271404117926S/

BE11:45am

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Which leads us into Sports Direct results.

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 406.70, down 29.4 (-6.74%), High: 427.80, Low: 385.50, Volume: 1.18m
BE11:46am

They're okay. Sales are pretty terrible but margins are improving.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

And you have a mark-to-market writeoff on Debenhams but, since that's a mark-to-market, that should've been in the price already.

BE11:48am

So .... the drop seems to be tied to Sports Direct supporting earnings by keeping a lid on capex

BE11:50am

Which, if correct, is a slightly odd strategy against its stated longer term ambition of becoming the Selfridges of Sportswear.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

RBC incoming.

BE11:50am

Sports Direct has a strong position in UK sports retailing and asset backing from strategic stakes in other retailers, but we think it will be challenging to execute on its strategy to upgrade its brand and store portfolio in the UK and SPD may face dollar sourcing pressure again later next year owing to the recent fall in the £ versus the USD.
International expansion has proved more challenging than we expected and SPD faces opex pressure from higher labour costs.
Finally we expect ROCE to come under further pressure as capital intensity rises as a result of SPD's acquisitions of freeholds and as it moves more into premium fashion. Sports Direct trades at 9x CY18E lease-adjusted EBITDAR slightly ahead of the sector UK general retail sector average of 8x.

Bryan good morning guys
Deep Breath everyone... @BE - expect another RNS explaining why lower capex will in no way impact " innovative initiatives such as our strategic investments and partnerships"
BE11:52am

And Jonathan Pritchard at Peel Hunt, who's always an entertaining read.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Management has been obsessive about its attempts to elevate product and raise store standards. Clearly this is working, but it comes from a low base: Sports Direct is the naughty kid who used to be in detention every week and is now mending his ways: there’s a long way still to go to become the real teacher’s pet of the brands. Indeed, we believe that Sports Direct’s attempts at elevation have a ceiling. The product range and client base are completely different to JD, and that will continue: Sports Direct will serve its shoppers in an increasingly appropriate way, but we’d say that there is no chance of it reverting back to the toe-to-toe battles with JD: the offers have completely diverged. That doesn’t mean that Sports Direct can’t continue to prosper in its territory, but we think that the upside from an elevation perspective is capped.

BE11:52am

He's on a 450p target, "which would imply a structural growth average multiple of 18x."

undefined
Penny E-sure looks cheap to me.
Bryan it may be quite interesting an operation that there is with Arrow Global,you know about it?

rw42 @PC - saw some gumph this morning about MoneySuperMarket trying to 'digitise' the mortgage business - good luck to them!

11:57 am

Second warning of the year from them.

cheeckychappy Hiya - been stuck in a meeting
BE11:58am

Oh, and the FD's gone. Bill Gow. He's off to join the family business.

Mr Diamond Sports Direct / Mashley has a stake in GOAL?
BE11:58am

Here's Canaccord, which I'll venture is shop.

cheeckychappy but just a few things. A - could we revisit BE's Monkey's Toss comment from yesterday...
11:58 am
BE11:58am

UK trading started strongly this year but the Goals Achilles heel is snow and all clubs were affected by the two bouts of snowy weather in March. This has caused a further unprecedented knock-on impact on trading throughout Q2 due to amateur 11-a-side games deferred to Q2 when players would normally have migrated to playing 5-a-side. Goals is highly operationally geared and is vulnerable to changes in L4L sales. H1 L4L sales declined 3% to £16.1m (LY: £16.6m). At 18 weeks L4L sales were -1.9%, having been at +4.0% for the first eight weeks of the year. We estimate L4L sales fell to c.-6.5% for weeks 8 to 18 and c.-4% for Q2. Q3 is the quietest quarter of the year and we expect trading to have been predictably poor during the FIFA World Cup but Goals should enjoy an uplift which should continue into September when the autumn leagues kick-off.

BE11:58am

Weaker trading has not pushed Goals into breach with banking covenants, nor has it affected summer capex plans. Year-end net debt/EBITDA at 2.97x was a whisker below the 3.0x covenant. The covenant is tested quarterly and Goals passed the March test. For June and September, the covenant test has been relaxed to 3.25x to provide extra headroom and it is encouraging that Goals has confirmed that it will continue to push ahead to invest another £3m on 90 new pitches (12 completed in H1) in the 18 clubs that have four or less upgraded arenas with the work scheduled for the quieter summer months. Post this refurbishment, 73% of the Goals estate will have been upgraded, reducing the average pitch age to 3.2 years. At end FY17, Goals had refurbished 248 arenas, representing 53% of the total pitches.

Goals continues to make good progress in the US with its JV partner City Football Group. South Gate is performing well, trading continues to build at Pomona and Rancho. Construction of the fourth club at Covina, Los Angeles, is under way and should open in Q4. Two more new clubs are scheduled for FY19. The UK expenditure is ring-fenced and the US does not draw on UK cash flow.

cheeckychappy Also - punchy lobbing Prudential and Aggrekko (spelt incorrectly I'm sure) as bid targets
BE11:59am

("South Gate"? That's pretty fortunate.)

cheeckychappy Prudential!!!!!!
cheeckychappy Last week AstraZeneca

Blank canvas thanks for everything today - another classy performance from both sides of the page

12:01 pm
Moneysupermarket.Com Group PLC (MONY:LSE): Last: 331.60, up 22.3 (+7.21%), High: 348.00, Low: 317.30, Volume: 2.27m
Paper Chase Ah thanks BE
Alchemy30 @cheecky, do you know :-)
BE12:02pm

Numbers fine, guidance fine, fuel bill switching trends seem to be improving.

BE12:02pm

UBS can summarise:

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Group revenues came in at £173.7m in 1H18, +1% above UBSe of £172m. Adj. EBITDA was £62.2m in 1H, 5% below UBSe of £65.2m and adj. EPS were 8.4p, 4% below UBSe of 8.7p/sh. Gross profit margin was 71.6% below UBSe of 73.4%.

BE12:02pm

Home services revenues were strong at +23% in 1H18. YoY revenue growth in the insurance segment was robust at +4% YoY in 1H18 despite the challenging price environment. Money was up +2% in 1H recovering from a weaker Q1.

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
Penny Money Supermkt - looked like short covering first thing. Stock was up 12/13% at one stage
BE12:02pm

The company has stated it is confident to meet market expectations in terms of adj. EBITDA between £123.7m and £128m vs. UBSe of £124.8m.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: The recovery in the core energy switching business will likely be taken positively, but there might be some concerns around 120bps YoY gross margin decline.

cheeckychappy Apologies meant "what it is" earlier...
cheeckychappy @Alchemy30 - maybe...
BE12:03pm

And Numis.

BE12:04pm

All in there was a fear heading into this set of results they could be disappointing, that is not the case. A good set of numbers that at the very least firmly underpin FY estimates, and an encouraging statement with regards to strategy and new product launch. No change to estimates, but risk on upside as we move through year. We remain very comfortable with our BUY and 390p target.
